diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)

justification: Flushing, abdominal cramps, rhinorrhea, conjunctival injections, and angioedema are highly suggestive of an allergic reaction. This is an immune response to an allergen like food, medication, insect sting, or environmental trigger. The timing and severity can vary.}, {diagnosis: Anaphylaxis

justification: This is a severe, life-threatening allergic reaction. Angioedema, especially with respiratory symptoms (not mentioned but possible), necessitates immediate medical attention.}, {diagnosis: Drug allergy
justification: Similar to any allergic reaction, but specifically triggered by a medication. The timing depends on the drug and dosage.}, {diagnosis: Food allergy
justification: Common food allergens (nuts, shellfish, etc.) can cause these symptoms. Abdominal cramps are a strong indicator in this case.}, {diagnosis: Mastocytosis

justification: This rare disorder involves the over-accumulation of mast cells, which release histamine and cause allergic-like symptoms. Flushing is a hallmark symptom.}, {diagnosis: Hereditary angioedema
justification: This genetic condition causes episodes of swelling, often without itching or hives. Abdominal pain is common.}, {diagnosis: Systemic mastocytosis
justification: Similar to mastocytosis but affecting multiple organ systems, potentially leading to more severe symptoms like anaphylaxis.}, {diagnosis: Idiopathic anaphylaxis
justification: Anaphylaxis without a clear trigger after investigation.}, {diagnosis: ACE inhibitor angioedema
justification: Angioedema is a known side effect of ACE inhibitors (blood pressure medications), though other symptoms are less common.}, {diagnosis: Scromboid poisoning (histamine fish poisoning)
justification: Caused by eating improperly stored fish with high histamine levels. Flushing and gastrointestinal symptoms are typical.}
